0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-sanders-idUSKCN0ZN2DK	Sanders expected to endorse Clinton on Tuesday: New York Times	"
WASHINGTON Democrat Bernie Sanders is expected to endorse presidential rival Hillary Clinton on Tuesday at a campaign event in New Hampshire
column2: The New York Times reported on Thursday.Citing three Democrats who have been involved in the planning
column3: the Times said the endorsement was partly the result of daily talks between the candidates' campaign managers about bringing them together and advancing Sanders' policy priorities.The Sanders campaign declined to comment.Sanders
column4: a U.S. senator from Vermont
column5: has resisted endorsing Clinton in a show of party unity since she clinched the Democratic nomination last month. Sanders chose to continue his campaign as leverage to win concessions on his liberal policy agenda and reforms to the Democratic Party nominating process.

column1: In a speech to supporters last month
column2: Sanders vowed to help Clinton defeat Republican Donald Trump in the Nov. 8 election but did not end his campaign.Sanders risked being left behind
column3: however
column4: as other prominent Democrats have rallied around Clinton
column6: Vice President Joe Biden and U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren
column7: a favorite of the party's liberal wing.

column1: Clinton
column2: who shifted to the left under pressure from Sanders during the campaign
column3: adopted another of his issues on Wednesday when she proposed eliminating tuition at public colleges and universities for in-state students whose families earn less than $125
column4: 000 annually.

column1: Sanders' endorsement is expected to ensure he has a prominent speaking slot at the Democratic convention later this month
column2: the Times quoted the three Democrats as saying. (Writing by John Whitesides; Editing by Mohammad Zargham and Leslie Adler)"

column1: WASHINGTON President Barack Obama will speak with European leaders about the Syrian refugee crisis
column2: Russia and Ukraine
column3: and the aftermath of Britain's decision to pull out of the EU during the NATO summit on Friday
column4: the White House said.Speaking with reporters aboard Air Force One on Thursday en route to the summit in Warsaw
column5: White House spokesman Josh Earnest also said Obama and Russian President Vladimir Putin did not reach any agreement for new cooperation in Syria during a phone call they held on Wednesday.

column1: (Reporting by Ayesha Rascoe and Alana Wise; Writing by Tim Ahmann)"
2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-adviser-russia-idUSKCN0ZN294	Trump adviser
column2: on Moscow visit
column3: dodges questions about U.S. policy on Russia	"

column1: MOSCOW A foreign-policy adviser to U.S. presidential candidate Donald Trump avoided all questions about how the United States should shape its policy toward Russia on a visit to Moscow on Thursday.Carter Page said at a lecture he gave to students and business figures organized by Moscow's New Economic School that he did not want to comment on the U.S. election campaign.Page declined to say whether he was planning to meet anyone from the Kremlin
column2: the Russian government or Foreign Ministry during his visit.Trump
column3: the front-runner for the Republican nomination for the U.S. presidential election
column4: has made contradictory comments about Russia but made headlines with warm words for President Vladimir Putin. Putin called Trump ""very talented""
column5: fuelling speculation the Kremlin would be pleased to see Trump in the White House
column6: but later rowed back from those comments.

column1: In his lecture on Thursday
column2: Trump's adviser Page said Western governments had often had a hypocritical focus on democratization
column3: corruption and inequality in the post-Soviet world.He also accused the United States and its partners of ""proactive steps to encourage regime change overseas"".

column1: This may understandably advance a certain level of insecurity
column2: Page said.Relations between the United States and Russia have deteriorated sharply under U.S. leader Barack Obama
column3: undermined by disagreements over the conflicts in Ukraine and Syria.

column1: The Obama administration imposed sanctions on Russia in 2014 over Russia's annexation of Ukraine's Crimea region and fights on the opposing side of the five-year-old Syrian civil war.Page worked in Russia for U.S. investment bank Merrill Lynch in the mid-2000s and said in an interview with Bloomberg in March that he was an investor in Russian gas producer Gazprom. (Reporting by Alexander Winning; Editing by Toby Chopra)"
3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-guantanamo-uruguay-idUSKCN0ZN25V	U.S. lawmakers blast Obama administration over ex-Guantanamo prisoner	"
By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. lawmakers sharply criticized President Barack Obama's administration on Thursday over the disappearance of a former Guantanamo detainee
column2: calling for an end to transfers from the prison because of fears former prisoners could launch attacks on Americans.They also raised concerns about reports that Jihad Diyab
column3: a Syrian among six detainees resettled in Uruguay in December 2014
column4: has disappeared and may now be in Brazil.Obama is working to close the U.S. military prison at Guantanamo Bay
column5: where terrorism suspects have been held for 15 years
column6: by transferring detainees not considered security threats to foreign countries.Republican lawmakers worry that the Obama administration is so eager to close the prison before he leaves office in January that it is sending detainees to countries that cannot ensure they will not return to the battlefield by joining militant groups that target Americans and U.S. allies.""You're talking about detainees who have every intent of killing American families
column7: Republican Representative Joe Wilson of South Carolina said at a House of Representatives Foreign Affairs Committee hearing. The administration has considered sending Guantanamo detainees to a prison in South Carolina.The New York Times reported that Diyab said last month he was going on a religious retreat that would last into next week
column8: and would be unreachable by telephone or email.Since then
column9: some Uruguayan officials said they lost track of him and suggested he may have traveled to Brazil
column10: the newspaper reported.""Many countries just aren't up to the job
column12: the committee's chairman. ""... Yet the administration has sent Guantanamo terrorists to these countries anyway.""

column1: Republican and some Democratic committee members sharply questioned Lee Wolosky
column2: the State Department's special envoy for closing the Guantanamo detention center
column3: and Paul Lewis
column4: his Pentagon counterpart.Representative Jeff Duncan
column7: charged with forging passports for al Qaeda
column8: could pose a threat to the upcoming Olympics in Rio de Janeiro
column9: if he were indeed at large in that country.The committee's ranking Democrat
column11: who backs the closure of the detention center in Cuba
column12: said it was important to keep the issue in perspective.""Under no circumstances
column14: is the Obama administration simply opening the gate and releasing dangerous terrorists onto the street

column1: FEW RETURN TO BATTLEFIELD

Lewis and Wolosky said only 5 percent of detainees transferred since Obama became president have been confirmed to have returned to the battlefield. The percentage was higher for the over 500 released under President George W. Bush.There are currently 79 detainees at Guantanamo
column2: of whom 29 are eligible for transfer.

column1: Wolosky acknowledged Diyab had been ""difficult"" from the time he was transferred to Uruguay. According to the Times
column2: Diyab's friends and supporters say he is off praying and will re-emerge soon.Obama has been trying to make good on his 2009 pledge to close the facility. But Congress has passed laws making it more difficult to do so
column3: chiefly by barring transfers to U.S. prisons.Lawmakers are unlikely to lift those restrictions
column4: especially in an election year. They have proposed even tighter controls on transfers in a fiscal 2017 defense policy bill
column5: one reason Obama has threatened a veto.Guantanamo opponents say holding prisoners for years without charge or trial goes against fundamental U.S. values and since they are Muslims
column6: is a recruiting tool for Islamist militants.Many Republicans insist the prison is an essential tool for handling suspects who threaten the United States. Donald Trump
column8: has called for the prison's expansion. (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Cynthia Osterman)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-guns-ryan-idUSKCN0ZN1WG	House Speaker Ryan: all options on table over Democrats' gun sit-in	"

WASHINGTON U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan said on Thursday ""all options"" were being considered over the possible discipline of House Democrats for protests they held on the House floor to call for action on gun-control measures.With Democrats already rejecting a Republican gun bill and warning of further protests
column2: the Republican-controlled House appeared to be heading for renewed discord over gun restrictions following the June 12 mass shooting at a gay nightclub in Orlando
column3: Florida.Ryan
column4: who was speaking at a news conference
column5: had previously said the House would vote this week on a measure intended to keep guns out of the hands of people the government suspects of involvement in violent extremism. But it is no longer clear when a vote might be held.

column1: Democrats say the Republican-backed legislation is inadequate because authorities would have only three days to convince a judge that a gun sale should be blocked.
(Reporting by Richard Cowan; Writing by Eric Walsh; Editing by Tim Ahmann)"
5	http://reuters.com/article/us-imf-lagarde-trade-idUSKCN0ZN1VU	IMF's Lagarde warns against Trump-style protectionism: FT	"

WASHINGTON International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde warned in an interview published on Thursday that anti-trade policies like those championed by Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump risked a protectionist movement that could severely damage global growth.Lagarde told the Financial Times that with Britain's vote to leave the European Union already casting a shadow over global growth
column2: the imposition of new trade barriers in another larger economy could have ""disastrous"" effects.""I think it would be quite disastrous
column3: actually. Well I don't think I should say disastrous because that is an excessive word and I should refrain from excessive words. But it would certainly have a negative impact on global growth
column4: she told the FT in response to a question about such policies.The newspaper said that while Lagarde made clear her negative views of anti-trade rhetoric and policies
column5: she refrained from referring to Trump by name or singling out any politician.

column1: Lagarde also told the FT that she doubted that a prolonged period of uncertainty over Britain's exit
column2: without triggering formal separation negotiations
column3: would be politically sustainable.""We want to see clarity sooner rather than later because we think that a lack of clarity feeds uncertainty
column4: which itself undermines investment appetites and decision making

column1: In a separate interview with Agence France Presse
column2: Lagarde said Brexit was unlikely to cause a world recession
column3: adding that the immediate effects would hurt the UK
column4: with some spillover to the euro area.

column1: She told AFP that proposals in Britain to cut corporate tax rates to 15 percent from 20 percent to counter the damage caused by the UK's EU divorce was a ""race to the bottom"" that would hurt other economies. (Reporting By David Lawder; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama)"
6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-fbi-idUSKCN0ZN1LS	FBI director says Clinton did not lie
column2: break law in email handling	"

column1: WASHINGTON FBI Director James Comey told lawmakers on Thursday that Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton did not lie to the FBI about her handling of emails as secretary of state and did not break the law.Comey told a Republican-led oversight panel in the U.S. House of Representatives that no reasonable prosecutor would charge Clinton with a crime over her use of private email servers while she was secretary of state
column2: some of which were used to transmit classified information.

column1: (Reporting by Julia Edwards; Writing by David Alexander; Editing by Eric Walsh)"
7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-ryan-idUSKCN0ZN14Z	U.S. House speaker asks that Clinton be denied classified data	"
By Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Top Republicans in the U.S. Congress pressed for sanctions on Thursday against Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton for mishandling classified information
column2: with House Speaker Paul Ryan formally asking she be denied such information during the campaign.Ryan
column3: the top Republican in the House of Representatives
column4: sent a letter to Director of National Intelligence James Clapper saying denying Clinton access to classified information would be an appropriate sanction for her mishandling of classified data while she was secretary of state.Ten Republican senators said on Thursday they had written Secretary of State John Kerry asking that the State Department immediately suspend security clearances of Clinton and aides Huma Abedin
column6: Jake Sullivan and other former State Department employees for security violations.The calls for sanctions against Clinton come after FBI Director James Comey rebuked her on Tuesday for ""extremely careless"" handling of classified information while using private email servers for business while secretary of state during President Barack Obama's first term.

column1: Comey recommended no criminal charges be filed but indicated administrative sanctions could be taken against Clinton or her aides. Attorney General Loretta Lynch on Wednesday accepted Comey's recommendation that no criminal charges were warranted and closed the case.Republican lawmakers and Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump have expressed outrage that the case was not being pursued.Ryan
column2: in a letter dated Wednesday
column3: formally asked Clapper to ""refrain from providing any classified information to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton for the duration of her candidacy for president"" because of the FBI's findings. The letter was obtained by Reuters from a source familiar with the matter.

column1: Ryan
column2: a Republican vice presidential candidate in 2012
column3: said he was aware Clinton would begin receiving classified intelligence briefings after the Democratic National Convention if she is formally nominated as expected. Presidential candidates are customarily provided such briefings.""Given the FBI's findings
column4: denying Secretary Clinton access to classified information certainly constitutes appropriate sanctions

column1: Republican senators
column2: including former Republican presidential candidate Marco Rubio
column3: said in their letter to Kerry that it was clear from Comey's comments on Tuesday that Clinton and her aides should have their security clearances immediately suspended if they still have them.""There is simply no excuse for Hillary Clinton's decision to set up a home-cooked email system which left sensitive and classified national security information vulnerable to theft and exploitation by America's enemies
column4: the letter said. (Additional reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Writing by David Alexander; Editing by Eric Walsh and Bill Trott)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-lynch-idUSKCN0ZM2IU	U.S. attorney general closes Clinton email probe
column2: says no charges	"

column1: By Richard Cowan
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The investigation into Hillary Clinton's use of private email while secretary of state is closed
column2: U.S. Attorney General Loretta Lynch said on Wednesday
column3: removing a legal cloud that threatened the presumptive Democratic nominee's presidential bid.  Lynch said she accepted the Federal Bureau of Investigation's recommendations that no charges be brought in the probe
column4: as Republicans made clear they would not let Clinton's email headaches fade away easily.""I received and accepted their unanimous recommendation that the thorough
column5: year-long investigation be closed and that no charges be brought against any individuals within the scope of the investigation
column6: Lynch said in a statement.With the Nov. 8 U.S. presidential and congressional elections beginning to heat up
column7: Republicans called on the administration to make public key documents in the Clinton email case.Donald Trump
column8: the presumptive Republican nominee for president
column9: speaking at a campaign rally in Cincinnati
column13: of bribing Lynch to decide not to press charges.He was referring to reports
column14: including in the New York Times this week
column17: might ask Lynch to stay on as attorney general.""She said she's going to reappoint the attorney general and the attorney general is waiting to make a determination as to whether or not she's guilty. And boy was that a fast determination
column23: the No. 3 House of Representatives Republican
column24: reacted to Lynch's announcement by proclaiming: ""Secretary Clinton broke the law and lied about it.""

column1: Senior Senate Republicans insisted that the FBI's investigation be made available to the public
column2: including a transcript of the more than three hours Clinton spent last Saturday in an interview conducted by the agency.Shortly before Lynch's announcement
column3: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell told reporters
column4: ""I think the next step...is to compare what Hillary Clinton said to the FBI with what Hillary Clinton's been saying to all of us over the last couple of years during this controversy.""In a blistering attack on Clinton
column7: said on the Senate floor: ""The bottom line is Secretary Clinton actively sought out ways to hide her actions as much as possible"" by using a private email account while heading the State Department. ""And in so doing
column8: she put our country at risk"" by leaving those emails vulnerable to computer hackers.Democrats have questioned Republicans' motives and accused them of squandering taxpayer dollars with lengthy investigations that have failed to uncover illegal activities.

column1: Republicans are in such desperate shape because of Trump (that) they would seize upon anything"" to divert attention
column2: said Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid.And Senator Patrick Leahy
column3: the senior Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee
column4: said in a statement following Lynch's announcement: ""This investigation is closed and that should be the end of this matter.""On Tuesday
column5: Federal Bureau of Investigation Director James Comey said Clinton
column7: had been ""extremely careless"" in her use of a private email server while she was secretary of state
column8: but he recommended no criminal charges be filed in the case.Comey
column9: who was deputy attorney general during the George W. Bush administration before becoming FBI director in 2013
column10: is scheduled to testify on Thursday before a House committee
column11: where Republicans and Democrats are expected to press him on his findings in the Clinton case.Lynch said she met on Wednesday afternoon with Comey and the career prosecutors and agents who had investigated whether Clinton broke the law as result of email servers kept in her Chappaqua
column13: home. One question is whether she mishandled classified information.

column1: House Speaker Paul Ryan

column5: Clinton should be denied access to classified information during the campaign.Presidential candidates normally get such briefings once they are formally nominated. McConnell

column8: saying in a statement on Tuesday it was pleased with the FBI decision. (Reporting by Eric Beech and Richard Cowan; Editing by Peter Cooney and Andrew Hay)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-smallbusiness-idUSKCN0ZN0SD	Democrat Clinton to propose plan to protect small businesses	"
NEW YORK Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton on Thursday will unveil proposals to help small businesses fight fraudulent practices by larger firms
column2: tactics her campaign will compare to the business record of her Republican rival
column3: Donald Trump.  The plan would enhance legal protections for small businesses when large firms don't pay their bills
column4: increase federal regulatory enforcement
column5: and expand working capital for small businesses
column6: according to a Clinton official.The proposal comes a day after Clinton
column8: lambasted Trump for what she described as profiting from exploiting workers in the slumping seaside town.A Reuters special report last year found Trump sometimes refuses to pay bills from contractors he has hired and then forces them to negotiate the final figure down.

column1: The new plan from the former secretary of state highlights a major division in the Democratic and Republican campaigns for the Nov. 8 presidential election. Trump
column2: a New York real estate developer
column3: often highlights his businesses as among his biggest qualifications for office
column4: promising to do for the country what he says he has done for his companies.

column1: But Clinton and others have harshly criticized Trump's business practices and argue that running a country is a far different proposition from running a private enterprise.
Clinton and several campaign surrogates will take her new small business proposal to 10 states
column2: including key election battlegrounds of Florida and Nevada
column3: pointing to Donald Trump's Atlantic City casino bankruptcies as a warning sign for voters. (Reporting by Luciana Lopez; Editing by Christian Schmollinger)"
